awd_abstract_narration:
This project will support a theoretical investigation into thermonuclear explosions on white dwarfs that are experiencing mass transfer from a nearby companion. This transfer of combustible fuel gives rise to explosive phenomena that is easily detectable in distant galaxies by the current and future optical surveys. Using the latest computational tools and techniques, this group will study outcomes from the transfer of helium onto white dwarfs and investigate the effects of gravity and acoustic waves on the creation and propagation of explosions.

White dwarfs are the dominant product of stellar evolution, forming at the rate of about one per year in a typical galaxy, but it requires special circumstances for two of them to end their lives in a binary with a short orbital period and the details of the explosion are not well understood.  The project is expected to have many implications for the study of stellar populations, stellar evolution, and cosmology, particularly in the upcoming era of massive surveys to detect gravity waves, short-period binaries, and peculiar supernovae.  Computational techniques from this project will be made freely available to the astrophysical community, and this group will continue ongoing efforts in science education and research training.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit


Our collaboration focused on developing improved theoretical predictions for the outcomes of accretion onto white dwarfs and their explosive outcomes. Our prime focus was on the impact of the accretion of helium onto white dwarfs made primarily of carbon and oxygen.  The detonation of the accreted helium was found to potentially also lead to a detonation of the underlying carbon and oxygen, creating a bright thermonuclear supernova. Our collaboration with the Palomar Transient Factory observational project also led to new insights into unusual transient phenomena in distant galaxies.


In detail, the major scientific results included:  


Helium Detonation Waves on White Dwarf Surfaces 


In an extended theoretical and computational effort, we studied the lateral propagation of a detonation wave in a thin layer of accreted helium on a white dwarf. Our initial work found that the rapid radial expansion leads to incomplete burning of the helium.  However, enough nuclear energy is released to sustain a laterally propagating detonation.  Though slower than the classic Chapman-Jouguet speed,these helium detonations are still fast enough to go around the star prior to the transit through the star of the inwardly propagating weak shock. We followed this work to show that the off-center ignition scenario for the carbon-oxygen core remains a viable way to trigger a much larger explosion that would be visible in distant galaxies.


 Physics of the Most Recurrent Novae 


For many years, the intermediate Palomar Transient Factory (iPTF) has been collecting nightly data of the Andromeda (M31) galaxy, creating a unique data set for explorations of variable stars within that nearby spiral galaxy. In December 2013, iPTF detected a classical novae in M31 that, due to the thorough coverage of M31, was quickly identified as a recurrent novae with a recurrence time of one year or less. Through subsequent theoretical work, we showed that the rapid recurrence time for these unstable flashes of accumulated hydrogen implied that the accreting white dwarf has a mass very close to the Chandrasekhar value, making this binary one of the few that are known to be near either ignition of carbon in their core or collapse to a neutron star.


Helium Accretion and Explosion Scenarios 


We performed a full re-investigation of mass transfer between a low-mass helium star and a white dwarf in a short-period binary utilizing the newly developed binary module in Modules for Experiments in Stellar Astrophysics (MESA).  The study detailed the state of the resulting helium shells and their explosions on the WD surface. We found that the first flash is usually the largest, and meets the requirements for triggering dynamical burning and developing a deflagration or detonation and sustaining a laterally propagating detonation within the He shell. Our subsequent modeling of a known binary in our galaxy also showed that it will likely have a bright explosive event soon after it starts transferring matter in 40 million years. 


Broader Impact


This grant led to the training of undergraduate students and graduate students in research.  We also gave many public talks that disseminated the results of our research to the public at large. All of the graduate students also fully participated in the 2013, 2014, 2015 and 2016 MESA Summer Schools, giving them an opportunity to share their detailed knowledge with over 100 students in the last four years.
